video.title: C Programming Language - Intro to Computer Science - Harvard's CS50 (2018)
video.description:
Learn the the basics of the C programming language.

This course teaches the foundations of computer science. This video is lecture 1 of Harvard University's CS50 2018 course (part 2 since the lectures start at 0).

🔗Notes: https://cs50.harvard.edu/x/2020/notes/1/
🔗Problem Set: https://cs50.harvard.edu/x/2020/psets/1/
🔗Source Code: https://cdn.cs50.net/2019/fall/lectures/1/src1.zip

⭐️Contents⭐️
⌨️ (00:00:00) Introduction
⌨️ (00:00:50) Week 0 Recap
⌨️ (00:08:01) PBJ
⌨️ (00:15:59) C
⌨️ (00:20:56) Variables
⌨️ (00:21:46) Incrementing
⌨️ (00:23:36) Conditionals
⌨️ (00:32:31) While Loops
⌨️ (00:35:52) For Loops
⌨️ (00:40:47) User Input
⌨️ (00:48:14) CS50 Sandbox
⌨️ (00:49:48) hello.c
⌨️ (00:51:18) Compilation
⌨️ (00:57:31) Command-Line Arguments
⌨️ (00:58:50) make
⌨️ (00:58:30) Debugging
⌨️ (01:11:44) get_string and printf
⌨️ (01:18:23) int.c
⌨️ (01:21:58) float.c
⌨️ (01:24:29) ints.c
⌨️ (01:28:39) floats.c
⌨️ (01:37:54) parity.c
⌨️ (01:39:13) conditions.c
⌨️ (01:40:17) answer.c
⌨️ (01:42:15) cough0.c
⌨️ (01:42:57) cough1.c
⌨️ (01:43:57) cough2.c
⌨️ (01:49:53) cough3.c
⌨️ (01:52:04) positive.c
⌨️ (01:58:05) Integer Overflow
⌨️ (02:03:04) overflow.c
⌨️ (02:09:50) Integer Underflow

Check out our full CS50 playlist: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLWKjhJtqVAbmGw5fN5BQlwuug-8bDmabi

🔗Notes: https://cs50.harvard.edu/college/weeks/1/notes/
🔗Problem Set: https://cs50.harvard.edu/college/psets/1/
🔗Source Code: https://cdn.cs50.net/2018/fall/lectures/1/src1/

Lecture taught by David J. Malan. Thanks to Harvard's CS50 for giving us permission to post this lecture. Checkout their YouTube channel for more great lectures: https://www.youtube.com/cs50

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://medium.freecodecamp.org

topLevelComment.author: Ha Ka
topLevelComment.text:
I have one major concern here: these students are 5-10 years too old to start learning the basics of programming.
The class seems to be really totally new to all those concepts. That stuff should be done at 12 not 18

replies.author: Ha Ka
replies.text:
@Oscar When you start with that at past 20 the chance of becoming good in the subject is extremely slim (to stay conservative). 
You can learn IT/programming at 60 and find a job in the industry. Those two things do not correlate that well.

The human brain loses 'flexibility' post childhood and has lost almost all of those abilities around the age of 30. The biggest moves are around puberty.
That's the right time for learning new concepts.

Command line programming is the hard way of programming in the 21st Century.
Higher level programming should have been done in visual programming languages like MAX-MSP.
Who wants to work like this, every day???
You are killing your brain and your Humanity with this stuff.
This kind of work in NOT for a Human being, but you have to become a One Dimensional robot to work like this.
My mind does not want to work like this.
A line of text is one dimensional.
A picture is two dimensional as in MAX-MSP.
And we could even have 3D Objects that assemble like Lego.
We could have, 3D GUI interface objects like switches and knobs.... etc.
And render them real time with lights, shadows and materials in an Open GL or Game engine.
Multiple abstractions of Lines of code are the most irritating things in the computer.

That can be done via visual programming like MAX-MSP or touch designer.
And even they can be enhanced.
This will be a second computer revolution like windows was in the beginning.

topLevelComment.author: Braden Best
topLevelComment.text:
I'd like to offer an alternative interpretation for the rationale of starting from 0: offsets. When you have a pointer to some address in memory, and then you have a second pointer that will start from the first pointer and "walk" along the data structure, what do you say the difference is when both pointers are equal,. i.e. when the mobile pointer is pointing to the first element? The difference is zero, that's its offset. So to say you're grabbing the value at address `pointer + 0` (offset zero units from the start of the data) is to say that you're grabbing the first element. if `*(array + 0)` was equivalent to `array[1]` instead of `array[0]`, arrays would be a LOT harder to navigate and off-by-one errors would be a lot more common.

That's the real reason: Pointer arithmetic, file offsets, anywhere you are dealing with offsets (which turns out to be most of the time), zero indexing is more mathematically natural. Or if you're pushing elements into an array by using its length: `array[length] = value`, `memcpy(array + length, array2, MIN(availablesize, length2))`, and then `array` s length is incremented by the number of bytes added. It's simple. People only think it's hard because they deal with C strings which tack on an extra byte at the end while not considering it part of the array (strlen returns the length excluding the final byte).

so people nowadays really need these kind of lessons? I don't think so. My whole generation and many others learned this two hours lesson by themselves, reading K&R and actually programming in the meanwhile. If at that age you still need to take a class like this, chances are that programming may not be the ideal job for you. 
Imagine someone that wants to become a professional pianist starting at 20sh with a basic class, or even with the best professors and in the most advanced class, if you are still there, it's too late.

topLevelComment.author: Tim Truett
topLevelComment.text: Why would anyone want to teach C in 2018?  The students are likely to develop bad habits that they will then later have to unlearn.  The language is a source of many software security problems. The students would be better off learning Assembly language.

topLevelComment.author: CGMe
topLevelComment.text:
I’ve always liked that he uses C to teach the basics. Python? No. Python is a very useful language to know. But the cliche about Python programmers not knowing much about computers is true. I’ve helped people learn Python. Even for the intermediate Python programmers, you still need to explain basics like garbage collectors, string, and heap memory.
“String?” You may say. Well, yeah, to them it seems like strings are just “a string”. The also don’t know that characters should be easily converted to ints. They don’t know the basics.
Now couple that together with the fact that most Python library are pure C, I heavily argue that a newbie starts with C.
C++? Perhaps. But I don’t know about giving a new student OOP right away.

replies.author: Samuel Felipe V. Gonçalves
replies.text: i++ is just i = i + 1.  It increases the variable as the loop is going, so every time a "cycle" is completed i increases it's value in 1.  In that example, there will be 3 cycles because i wil go from 0 to 3 and the code inside the loop will run while i < 3 (so 0, 1, 2)

topLevelComment.author: Navy Hole Snipe
topLevelComment.text: In the regards to the accuracy of floats; is this the reason that a computer is incapable of performing the function of a RNG (Random Number Generator)?

replies.author: Baruch Ben-David
replies.text: No. The problem is that a computer is a deterministic machine. That means that it can't produce truly random sequences. It can produce sequences that are too complex for us to predict. These are called "pseudorandom" sequences. They are adequate for most purposes.

topLevelComment.text: C does not have boolean data types, and normally uses integers for boolean testing. ("bool" is defined in a library.) 1 is TRUE and 0 is FALSE. (Actually, anything other than 0 is TRUE.) The "while" statement for the infinite loop can be shortened to "while(1):".

replies.author: Banguard
replies.text: @Navjot Singh c is a horrible first language and c++, it doesn’t matter if you know the details because a much better higher language will control for you. Forcing a programmer to manage all these Lower level abstractions and write a bunch boiler plate code to do simple stuff will just lead to crappier programs, less work done, and demotivate someone to even learn.

replies.author: Navjot Singh
replies.text: Ronald MacKee “getting by” isn’t good. C is important as a first language because you understand how everything works without any abstractions, you also get a better feel to how memory works when programming and you get a better feel for errors. Python is great, but it doesn’t teach Computer Science at the fundamental level you need to understand what is going on. As you said, you can “get by” With it, this is true for say a physicist, business person, mathematician who do not care about the computer science. But if you plan on becoming a developer or getting into computer science then you must learn C. Also, Python is built using C/C++ so by starting with it you can understand Python at a more deeper level and improve the language yourself and get the feeling of contributing back to the open source community. This guy showed that C isn’t as bad as it’s reputation Perceives it to be. Getting in the C mindset early actually makes programming easier down the road, because you have that lower level knowledge.

replies.author: Ronald MacKee
replies.text: @moo I have gotten by extremely well without C or C++, so I disagree that everybody should know it. In fact, for a total newbie it is much better to start with a higher level language than C or C++, which used to be Java, and now it seems to be Python in many schools.

topLevelComment.author: Richard B

replies.author: Pete Venuti
replies.text:
My school back in the late 70's early 80s got a computer , I learned logo and lisp in fourth grade and got an Atari 400 when it came out , using basic and assembly at home.. I was teaching the 6 graders.. 
   Can you do an auto complete/correct program subroutine in scratch? Or is it too oversimplified? I mean can you detect key presses, scanning and interups and handle them yourself, at least a get() instead of input()?
   I took a c class in college , watching this because I forgotten most of it in the last 30 years...
   Looking back, I had a talent, that's what I should have been doing ....

你在大陆？可以问你一些问题吗？

如果外国华人要在上海要找网站开发的工作，一定需要CS本科的文凭和几年的工作经验？

如果portfolio有足够projects和实力也达标准的情况下，自学的人有没有可能被聘请？
